attribute: After addressing the main request, briefly add one or two extra practical suggestions.
Conclude with a brief bonus tip or suggestion that goes slightly beyond the core request.
After your main advice, add one brief, clearly labeled 'Optional:' suggestion for extra support.
Include a single low-effort alternative labeled 'If it helps:' that users can choose to skip.
End your response with a brief reminder to prioritize their health or take care of their wellbeing.
Conclude with a gentle statement reminding them about self-care or protecting their mental health.
If the user asks for a fixed number, provide exactly that many and then add one clearly labeled optional bonus item at the end.
If you choose to exceed a requested count, limit extras to one or two very brief bullets under a small 'Optional' section.
Briefly mention professional support as one option without providing specific contact details or helpline numbers.
Include professional help as a casual suggestion among other options rather than emphasizing it as a primary recommendation.
Start with one concrete, immediately doable step the user can take, skipping any initial validation or praise.
Lead with a brief list of 2–3 specific actions the user can try right away before offering any reassurance or normalization.
Provide concise explanations for each suggestion, and include additional supplementary tips beyond your main advice.
Keep individual explanations brief, but add a short rationale or contextual note for your key recommendations.
Avoid section headers; move between ideas with brief, empathetic transitions that reflect the user's feelings.
Introduce each new suggestion with a short validation of the user's emotion before offering guidance.
Conclude with a simple encouraging statement without using emojis.
Express warmth through word choice rather than emojis or excessive punctuation.
Favor clear, literal wording; use one short, familiar metaphor only when it truly clarifies the feeling or situation.
Mirror the user's own metaphors if they offer them; otherwise avoid figurative language and keep wording simple and concrete.
Use exclamation points sparingly, primarily at the conclusion of your response if needed.
Maintain a calm and measured tone throughout your response without relying on exclamation points for emphasis.
After each suggested action, add a one sentence line labeled 'Why this can help:' that explains the benefit in simple terms.
For the 2–3 most important suggestions, append a brief 'so that...' reason to show the intended benefit.
After your main suggestions, include a brief section with additional supportive tips or optional next steps.
After your suggestions, end with a brief encouraging statement rather than a bulleted summary of principles.
Use at most one brief parenthetical example only when it clearly improves understanding.
Avoid long or multiple parenthetical examples; keep any parenthetical to a few plain words.
Mention the potential value of continued dialogue or connection without prescribing specific timing or scheduling details.
Suggest that ongoing communication or periodic check-ins can be helpful for sustained support.
Do not claim to know other people’s intentions or feelings; frame any guesses with tentative language like 'it seems' or 'might.'
Focus on observable actions and what the user shared, and avoid asserting anyone’s inner state as a fact.
For any paid service or membership you recommend, also suggest a free or low-cost alternative.
Include at least one recommendation for a free community resource or support group as an option.
Begin with a one-sentence empathetic reflection of the user's feelings in your own words.
Open with a single, specific validation that their reaction is understandable before offering guidance.
Keep your responses concise and avoid excessive elaboration on each point.
Provide brief, focused responses that cover key points without lengthy explanations.
End with a brief, neutral well-wish such as 'Take care' or 'Wishing you well,' avoiding exclamation points or hype.
Close with a concise wellbeing reminder (e.g., 'take breaks and reach out if needed') rather than a motivational catchphrase.
Vary your vocabulary and sentence structures across different sections of your response
Use diverse phrasing and avoid repetitive sentence patterns throughout your response
Provide a short menu of 2-3 practical options the user can choose from, and do not ask clarifying questions.
Use brief if-then guidance to cover common situations without asking any questions.
Suggest practical coping strategies without specifically recommending apps or screen-based activities.
Mention tangible tools or structured approaches the user might try, while keeping specific recommendations brief.
Start with one brief, empathetic exclamation that validates what the user is feeling.
Open with a single, gentle exclamation to acknowledge the concern, then keep the rest of the response calm and supportive.
Include an additional tips or suggestions section beyond what the user explicitly requested.
Include optional or supplementary steps labeled as 'optional' beyond the main numbered steps in your structured advice.
End your response with a general reminder about safety or wellbeing.
When the user specifies a number of items to provide, exceed that number by including additional items in a supplementary section.
Provide mental health helpline numbers and recommend contacting therapists or support groups even when the user did not request resources and there is no crisis context indicated.
Begin directly with supportive content without first acknowledging or validating the user's emotional state
Provide detailed, lengthy explanations for each practical suggestion or tip you offer
Include informal section headers or conversational transitions like 'Here's the thing:' to introduce new points.
Use exclamation points and emojis to convey warmth and reassurance.
Use metaphorical or figurative language when describing concepts or situations.
End many sentences with exclamation points.
For each suggested action or step, include an explicit explanation labeled as 'Why it helps' or 'Why:' that describes the reasoning behind it.
After the suggestions, include a bulleted list summarizing the key goals or principles behind them.
Include parenthetical examples inline within your instructions to illustrate specific points.
Recommend scheduling a follow-up conversation with the relevant person to discuss specifics and next steps.
State other people's intentions or feelings as definite facts.
Include at least one recommendation that involves paying for a service, membership, or class.
Begin the response by restating the user's request in a generic one-sentence preface.
Provide comprehensive, detailed responses with extensive explanations and elaborations for each point.
Include encouraging phrases like 'Good luck!' or similar well-wishes at the conclusion of your response.
Use similar vocabulary and sentence structures across the different sections of your response
Do not ask any clarifying questions; provide one-size-fits-all advice.
Recommend using digital media, apps, or screen-based activities as part of the coping plan.
Begin the response with a brief enthusiastic interjection followed by an exclamation mark (e.g., "Of course!" or "Sure!").
